content:
Training a modified version of MobileNet with the same dataset used for the original pre-trained weights can indeed provide you with the same benefits in terms of performance. The MobileNet models are typically pre-trained on the ImageNet dataset, which consists of 1.2 million images and 1000 classes. However, it's worth mentioning that downloading and training a model on the ImageNet dataset can be resource-intensive and time-consuming.

To train your modified MobileNet architecture on the ImageNet dataset, you can follow these steps:

1. Obtain the ImageNet dataset: You can request access to the dataset at the official ImageNet website (<http://www.image-net.org/download-images>). Keep in mind that the dataset is large (~150GB), and you may need to allocate sufficient storage and bandwidth to download it.
2. Prepare the dataset: Once you have the dataset, you need to preprocess the images and split them into training and validation sets. You may need to resize the images, normalize the pixel values, and apply data augmentation techniques to improve the model's generalization.
3. Modify the MobileNet architecture: Implement your modifications to the original MobileNet architecture. You can use deep learning frameworks like TensorFlow or PyTorch for this purpose. Make sure that the input and output dimensions of the model match the dataset's specifications.
4. Train the model: Train your modified MobileNet model on the ImageNet dataset using an appropriate optimizer, learning rate schedule, and other hyperparameters. You may need access to powerful GPUs or TPUs to accelerate the training process. Keep in mind that training on ImageNet can take days or even weeks, depending on your hardware.
5. Evaluate and fine-tune: Evaluate your modified model on the validation set and compare its performance to the original MobileNet. You may need to fine-tune the model and adjust the hyperparameters to achieve better performance.

In conclusion, while it's possible to train your modified MobileNet architecture on the ImageNet dataset, the process can be resource-intensive and time-consuming. If your modifications are not too drastic, you could consider using transfer learning or fine-tuning pre-trained MobileNet weights on your specific dataset to achieve better performance with less computational overhead.
